Award.AwardTitle: Oxidative Methods for C-C, C-N, and C-O Bond Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Marisa C. Kozlowski of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania to explore the development of methods for the formation of C-C, C-N, and C-O bonds by facile oxidative reactions. While dimerizations of phenol derivatives are abundant in biological systems, little progress has been made in the development of laboratory methods for the catalytic asymmetric formation of biaryls via oxidative dimerization. Studies to further elucidate the mechanism of this complex catalytic cycle will be undertaken. Higher homologs with interesting material/sensor properties, such as chiral bisnaphthoquinones, bisanthraquinones, and bisphenazines, will be generated using the developed methods and will be studied. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, broadening participation through the inclusion of underrepresented populations as researchers on the project, and continuing to build a groundbreaking program in high throughput experimentation that can be utilized routinely in a teaching environment.

This work could lead to more efficient methods for the preparation of this class of molecules. Such chemistry will contribute to environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis as oxygen is used as the terminal oxidizing agent. Successful development of the methodology will have a broad impact as there is an important need for synthetic methods in areas ranging from the pharmaceutical, chemical, materials science, and agricultural industries to basic biological and chemical research endeavors. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of students, from undergraduate to post-doctoral, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efficient synthesis of organic structures is critical to many areas of human endeavor including pharmaceuticals, agriculture, energy storage, and new devices.  While processes for the efficient formation of carbon-carbon bonds from simple readily available materials are very useful, such transformations are very difficult.  The development of new oxidative coupling chemistry leads to increases in efficiency due to lower step counts and smaller waste streams, because reaction sites no longer need to be preactivated in order to obtain a selective reaction. Inspired by nature's use of oxidative phenolic couplings to construct carbon-carbon bonds in many natural products, we have undertaken an investigation of these reactions resulting in several new, useful processes. Base metal catalysts (Cu, Fe), which are more sustainable, and environmentally benign oxidants, such as oxygen or air, have been the focus of this work.  Investigation into the exact factors governing the unique reactivity provides new insight to develop further new processes.  The products resulting from this work are useful in natural products synthesis, catalyst development, pharmaceutical synthesis, and polymer synthesis. As part of this work, a particularly exciting new compound was discovered that undergoes color changes is response to mechanical pressure (yellow to red) and that can be reversed chemically with gasoline type compounds (red to yellow). Applications are possible to sensing (e.g. to determine the content of diesel fuel, or Teflon contamination), reversible data storage, and structural overloads. Invaluable training in STEM areas to create a stronger workforce has been afforded to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars and visiting scholars.  

 


Last Modified: 01/12/2017
Modified by: Marisa C Kozlowski
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The efficient synthesis of organic structures is critical to many areas of human endeavor including pharmaceuticals, agriculture, energy storage, and new devices. While processes for the efficient formation of carbon-carbon bonds from simple readily available materials are very useful, such transformations are very difficult. The development of new oxidative coupling chemistry leads to increases in efficiency due to lower step counts and smaller waste streams, because reaction sites no longer need to be preactivated in order to obtain a selective reaction. Inspired by nature's use of oxidative phenolic couplings to construct carbon-carbon bonds in many natural products, we have undertaken an investigation of these reactions resulting in several new, useful processes. Base metal catalysts (Cu, Fe), which are more sustainable, and environmentally benign oxidants, such as oxygen or air, have been the focus of this work. Investigation into the exact factors governing the unique reactivity provides new insight to develop further new processes. The products resulting from this work are useful in natural products synthesis, catalyst development, pharmaceutical synthesis, and polymer synthesis. As part of this work, a particularly exciting new compound was discovered that undergoes color changes is response to mechanical pressure (yellow to red) and that can be reversed chemically with gasoline type compounds (red to yellow). Applications are possible to sensing (e.g. to determine the content of diesel fuel, or Teflon contamination), reversible data storage, and structural overloads. Invaluable training in STEM areas to create a stronger workforce has been afforded to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars and visiting scholars.
